This came up in another thread and I thought it was interesting enough to have its own. 
 
 CAFE stands for "Corporate Average Fuel Economy". CAFE standards were adopted in the wake of the 1973 oil embargo as part of an energy security bill. Prior to the adoption of CAFE, several states were either contemplating, or had bills in the works at the state level, that had the same impact (fuel efficiency requirements). Congress moved and passed CAFE with the support of the automakers because they argued that it would be far to expensive for them to produce different models for different states based on different criteria.
 
 CAFE has been examined in the courts and the courts have unanimously agreed that energy security has a profound impact on interstate commerce and that congress had a clear and compelling need to act to ensure energy security and that CAFE was absolutely a natural part of their powers under the commerce clause.
 
 Personally, I see no argument against the logic there.
 
 In the other thread, we kind of combined emissions standards with CAFE, even though they are completely different. 
 
 Emissions standards in the US were also passed under the commerce clause. They were actually introduced and argued primarily by republican senators from lumber states that were seeing vast stretches of prime timber being damaged by acid rain, decimating their resource value. Congress started passing emissions standards for automobiles primarily to combat the rise in sulphur dioxide from tailpipes that was causing the damage.
 
 The courts have ruled that since the impact of pollution is not localized and has a significant economic impact in other states, that enviromental regulations from congress are a legitimat euse of their power to regulate interstate commerce. For example, at one time the runoff from spraying in Nebraska and Iowa was entering the Kansas River, which was costing residents of Kansas, who pull and filter water from the river to drink, hundreds of millions of dollars per year in additional costs to filter out the agricultural chemicals being introduced upstream. Contaminates being dumped in the Missouri river at one time were so bad that farmers in Tenesee could not use the water to irrigate their crops. Acid rain produced by vehicles in California were wiping out valuable tracts of lumber in Oregon. 
 
 Again, I agree with the courts on this one. I can see a clear and logical connection between these regulations and interstate commerce. 
 
 Thoughts??
